chapter.title: Simple Sample Chapter
chapter.para: This chapter and are two chapters created to demonstrate some basic markup in DocBook. Note that both chapters demonstrate different things, as well as the fact that this chapter is flat, and the other chapter has nested sections.
Most DocBook stuff should be fairly straightforward. Its like HTML, with its own tag set. The only slightly "tricky" piece is linking and file layout.

This document has been divided into many .xml files. However, this is a "trick" from the XML parser. The docbook processor does not know this isn't one file. As such, anytime you name something keep in mind there is one namespace. Creating an element and tagging it ...id="details" will likely conflict. As such, the naming convention for everything is to prefix it with the file name. If you have nested sections, those go in front of any name as well. This also goes for any graphics images. See me if you're confused by this.

listitem.para: Never refer to an image with directional nouns. Do not write the image below as you do not know if the image will be below, or on the next page.

If you think someone may want to refer to your section/chapter/table, then give it a title with the <title> tag. Then, on the element itself, provide an ID attribute. Note that when someone links (via <xref>) to your content, their reference will cary the text of your title.
When using <xref>, always let the linkend define the text.
Do not assume your text will be a section, chapter, etc forever. It is best to avoid such positional language, as we may reorganize things
